answers.answer: I think you know the answer to this LOL...  But I think you probably want to know the details of why ;)1st all I can say is that you are on a fast track to being diabetic. Insulin is a hormone produced by the pancreas to control the amount of glucose (sugar) in the blood.  So it's your body's ability to deal with sugar.  Try to think of it as a rubber band.  Every time you consume something with sugar in it that rubber ban expands and then bounces back.  As you age... The rubber of an over-used elastic band may become brittle and have less memory to it.  Yet if you continue to consume sugar and force that weak elastic band to stretch & release over and over with every bit of sugar you introduce into your body... And you also have to remember carbs turn into sugar in your body too (especially things like instant rice, white bread), this puts yet more stress on that rubber band. One day it's NOT going to bounce back and THAT is when you become diabetic.  It sounds simple doesn't it...  That's because it really is ;)  Every time you put sugar in your body, think of that rubber band.Also.  You eat a sh*t load of refined sugar.  That my friend is BAD.  Not only does it totally lack nutrients but when you eat it, it actually robs your body of more nutrients, vitamins, minerals and enzymes. So, try to avoid products made with white sugar, corn syrup, high fructose corn syrup, sucrose, dextrose, fructose, and ALL artificial sweeteners.  Try to replace refined sugar with natural sweeteners- stevia, Rapadura (dehydrated cane sugar juice), maple syrup, molasses, honey. Many health food stores offer products made with natural sweeteners, like cookies and ice cream...  But even natural sugars have to be limited.My thinking is, you either make the change now when you are not diabetic and simply want to make the chage...  Rather than later when you are diabetic and facing blindness, kidney failure, microvascular disease, atherosclerosis, infections, diabetic ketoacidosis, amputations....  And much more.Taking control of sugar intake is HARD, especially in our society.  But it can be done!!

question: I consume mass amounts of sugar!  Whether it be cool aid, sweet iced tea or in my coffee.  The amount of white sugar that I consume in a week has to be harmful to me; or is it?  I mean I can drink a whole pitcher of cool aid in a couple of hours and there's at least 1 1/4 cup of sugar in each pitcher.  When I put sugar in my coffee I unscrew the sugar container to pour it in until I get the taste that I'm looking for.  My question is this; what are the health risks of consuming all this sugar?  I'm 38 years old and diabetes is very hereditary in my family.  Grant you every time I've ever had my blood sugar tested it's been fine.  I am however about 40 lbs over weight.  What are your thoughts?  Could this lead to diabetes in the future or does the amount of sugar that one consumes have anything to do with that?  Please respond....
